headline: Georgia GOP advances parent rights measure for public schools
sentences:

Principals would have three days to respond to requests, although schools could extend that period by up to 30 days.

The measure says parents have the right to review all classroom materials, the right to access all records relating to their child, the right to opt their child out of all sex education, and the right to prevent the creation of photos, videos and voice recordings of their children except for security purposes.

Georgia state senators on Tuesday passed a bill to codify parental rights in K-12 schools, part of a larger push on educational issues by Republicans nationwide, despite warnings from Democrats that the law will allow a few disgruntled parents to paralyze schools with burdensome demands.

Other bills pending in Georgia would allow parents to ask for inappropriate? materials to be removed, ban the teaching of divisive concepts? on race and prohibit transgender girls from playing on girls' sports teams.

Sen. Harold Jones II, an Augusta Democrat, said the law was so murkily drafted that it could allow parents to prevent their student from being recorded while playing football, meaning games couldn't be broadcast.

Sen. Elena Parent, an Atlanta Democrat, said that the ability for parents to demand to review all instructional material during the first two weeks of each nine-week grading period could cause trouble.
Conservative ferment over how schools teach about race, sexual orientation and other subjects is increasingly leading to calls for transparency mandates, like the one envisioned in the measure.
I believe that parents have a fundamental right in deciding what your children are taught in the classroom,? said Sen. Clint Dixon, a Buford Republican and Kemp floor leader.
Parents would be guaranteed a speaking slot before their local school board to appeal any denial, and could further appeal to the state Board of Education.
I don't know how you can go back to your districts and tell parents I'm against you,'? said Sen. Matt Brass, a Newnan Republican.
The law would require local school boards to develop procedures for parents to object to material used in the classroom.
Existing rules already require every school district to publish a list of the primary materials used in each class.
